The Church of Our Lady of the Immaculate Conception (Panjim Church) is an iconic landmark.
Used as a landmark for a meeting point.
This church stands tall for many years.
rich history
devotion to the Blessed Mother are palpable
This church houses the ancient bell that was removed from the Augustinian ruins of the Church of Our Lady of Grace.
This bell is considered to be the second largest of its kind in Goa, surpassed only by the Golden Bell which resides in the Se Cathedral.
Originally built as a chapel in 1541 for Portuguese sailors, it was expanded into its current grand structure in 1609.
The church's striking white facade and zigzagging staircases, inspired by the Bom Jesus de Braga in Portugal, make it a standout landmark in Goa.
The bell tower houses the second-largest bell in Goa, weighing around 2,250 kilograms.
This bell was salvaged from the ruins of the Augustinian Monastery and is affectionately known as the 'Golden Bell'.
The main altar is dedicated to Our Lady of the Immaculate Conception and is adorned with gold and silver decorations, reflecting the church's historical opulence.
Although not a UNESCO World Heritage site, the Church of Our Lady of the Immaculate Conception holds significant historical and cultural value.
A chapel was first built in Panaji in 1541 to serve the religious needs of Portuguese sailors at their first port of call in colonial Portuguese India.
At that time the settlement was a small fishing village.
It became a Parish in 1600.
In 1609 the small chapel was replaced by the present day large church to minister to the residents and sailors.
In the 18th century the stairways, in a symmetrical zigzag form, were added to the church.
The second largest church bell in Goa was installed in a bell tower in 1871.
It was formerly at the Augustinian Monastery on Holy Hill, and was retrieved after the monastery was damaged.
The church's vibrant history and cultural significance make it a must-visit.

The exterior facade of the church is rich with Portuguese Baroque style architectural elements is painted a bright white to signify the Immaculate virgin, Mary.
The tall belfry centered atop the facade houses the bell from the Augustinian Monastery.
The imposing facade is distinctive with its two towers and centrally placed taller belfry.
The church is laid out in the orthodox cruciform fashion with a nave and a transept.
The steps are possibly remodeled after the Nossa Senhora da Peneda Sanctuary in Penada and the Bom Jesus do Monte church in Braga, Portugal.

Shops & Stalls: You can also find some shops which sell a variety of accessories, etc.
In front side you have plenty of shops.
Fee shops selling mementos, purse etc. at reasonable rates.
Nearby food shops and shopping points available
Food & Local Cuisine: Nearby juice shop like Uncle Ji's.
Events & Entertainment: The best time to visit is during the Feast of Our Lady of the Immaculate Conception on December 8th, when the church comes alive with novenas, fairs, and vibrant fireworks.
The church is also famous for its annual feast on December 8th, when it is illuminated with colorful lights, and a grand fair takes place, complete with music and fireworks.
Navigation & Signage: limited informational displays might leave some visitors yearning for more historical context.
Amenities & Facilities: Candle burning point available for 50rs per candle
Value for Time & Money: worth visiting for its architectural beauty and historical significance.
